required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: AGE Levels in ER+ Metastatic Breast Cancer Patients Receiving Endocrine Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study of Pharmacologic Manipulation of AGE (Advanced Glycation Endproducts) Levels in ER+, Metastatic Breast Cancer Patients Receiving Endocrine Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to look at the effects that the study drugs (metformin and OPC) have on AGE levels in patients with ER+ metastatic breast cancer.

detailed_description.textblock: AGEs are a type of metabolite, or substance, found in the food. The AGE content in food is determined by the types of food you eat and also how you prepare your food. The researchers helping conduct this study have found a potential link between AGE levels and cancer. The purpose of this study is to see if certain drugs (metformin and OPC) have an effect on the AGE levels in your blood and to see if those AGE levels have an effect on your cancer.

primary_outcome.description: The primary objective is to determine if the test agents are able to reduce AGE levels by at least 30% in th 50% or more of test subjects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and changes to BMI
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and BMI will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and HOMA-IR will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and A1C
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and A1C will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and lipids
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and lipids will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and diet
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and diet will be described using graphs and other models. Diet will be assessed by using the NIH "Eating at America's Table Study Quick Food Scan" and the NCI "Quick Food Scan"

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and quality of life
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by FACT-B quality of life questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and plasma IL6
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and IL6 will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and leptin
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and leptin will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and c-reactive protein (CRP)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and CRP will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and malondialdehyde (MDA)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and MDA will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and oxLDLs (low density lipoprotein)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and oxLDLs will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between AGE level and sRAGE (soluble receptor for AGE)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in AGE levels and sRAGE will be described using graphs and other models.

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of adverse events as assessed by CTCAE v. 4
secondary_outcome.description: Toxicities will be tabulated by type, grade and the visit at which they occurred.

secondary_outcome.measure: Tumor response to treatment as assessed by RECIST 1.1 or MD Anderson criteria
secondary_outcome.description: The anti-tumor response will be measured by comparing baseline and post-treatment imaging using RECIST 1.1 or MD Anderson criteria for bone only disease.

arm_group.description: During week 1, subjects will take one metformin tablet in the morning and one OPC tablet in the morning and in the evening, about 12 hours apart. During weeks 2-12 the metformin tablet will be taken approximately 12 hours apart and one OPC about 12 hours apart, in the morning and in the evening.

intervention.description: Metformin is a drug typically given for the treatment of type II diabetes
OPC is a derivative of grape seed extract

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Must have ER+ breast cancer
- Metastatic disease; protocol does allow for bone-only disease
- Must be receiving endocrine therapy
- Must have completed at last 2 months of current endocrine therapy prior to registration
- Must have adequate hematologic, renal and hepatic function
- Prior/concurrent radiation therapy is allowed
- Prior chemotherapy is allowed, but last dose must have been at least 2 months prior to enrollment
- May have diabetes, but must not be taking metformin
- Must be able to swallow and retain oral medication
- Performance status of 0-2
- Treated stable brain metastases are allowed, as long as patient does not require steroids or anti-seizure medications
- Must be informed of the investigational nature of this study and must have the ability to sign informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known allergy to grapes or grape seed
- Known hypersensitivity or intolerance to metformin
- Any condition associated with increased risk of metformin-associated lactic acidosis (e.g., congestive heart failure defined as New York Heart Association {NYHA} Class III or IV functional status; history of acidosis of any type; habitual intake of 3 or more alcoholic beverages per day).
- More than two prior endocrine therapy regimens for the treatment of metastatic ER+ breast cancer.
- Concurrent use of restricted agents outlined in section 4.5.
- History of alcohol abuse within 2 years of registration.
